snippet: Decades after they were dug to provide material for an airstrip during World War II, “borrow pits” are eroding islanders’ quality of life in Tuvalu.
abstract: Funafuti Journal; residents of tiny Pacific island nation of Tuvalu, who are running out of land, have taken to building houses on so-called borrow pits, which were dug out by allied armies during World War II; pits are seawater mingled with household garbage and both human and animal wastes, and are hazardous to residents' health; rising sea levels associated with global warming threaten country's very existence.
lead_paragraph: Decades after they were dug to provide material for an airstrip during World War II, “borrow pits” are eroding islanders’ quality of life in Tuvalu.

headline.main: A Tiny Pacific Island Nation That Does Not Smell Like Paradise
headline.print_headline: A Tiny Pacific Island Nation That Does Not Smell Like Paradise
